page.title: 04Origins of Southwick
page.content: {The Canons of St. Mary's Church settled in the hamlet of Southwick, where they had been granted land. The site was secure and the position of the village ideal, being sheltered by Portsdown Hill and the periphery of the Forest of Bere, the chances of being attacked by raiders were therefore remote. Southwick was mentioned in the {Domesday Book lO86.}Common pasture was granted to everyone for their animals to graze on and they were permitted to use the Forest of Bere to collect firewood. The Priory and the convent were given permission to enclose 6OO acres of land and woodland to use. A number of l8th century documents have revealed that at that time the village comprised of a mill house, a malt house, an outhouse, an orchard and several small houses.
